seeds.name: Cherry Tomato
seeds.notes: Plant in full sun, 24-36 inches apart. Water consistently. Indeterminate.
seeds.germinationNotes: Start indoors 6-8 weeks before last frost. Keep soil consistently moist.

seeds.name: Nantes Carrot
seeds.notes: Sow seeds thinly in rows. Prefers loose, sandy soil. Keep soil free of weeds.
seeds.germinationNotes: Carrot seeds are small; mix with sand for easier sowing. Do not transplant.

seeds.name: Romaine Lettuce
seeds.notes: A cool-weather crop. Plant in early spring or fall. Can bolt in hot weather.
seeds.germinationNotes: Lettuce needs light to germinate, so do not cover seeds too deeply.

seeds.name: Genovese Basil
seeds.notes: Loves heat. Plant after the last frost. Pinch back leaves to encourage bushy growth.
seeds.germinationNotes: Keep soil warm (around 70°F) for best germination.

seeds.name: Jalapeño Pepper
seeds.notes: Loves sun and heat. Can be grown in containers. Wear gloves when handling seeds and fruit.
seeds.germinationNotes: Start indoors 8-10 weeks before last frost. Use a heat mat for best results.

seeds.name: Marketmore Cucumber
seeds.notes: Vining plant that needs a trellis. Prolific producer. Harvest often to encourage more fruit.
seeds.germinationNotes: Plant after all danger of frost has passed and soil is warm.

seeds.name: Lacinato Kale
seeds.notes: Also known as Dinosaur Kale. Very cold hardy. Flavor improves after a light frost.
seeds.germinationNotes: Can be direct-sown or started indoors 4-6 weeks before last frost.

seeds.name: French Breakfast Radish
seeds.notes: Fast growing cool-weather crop. Plant in succession for a continuous harvest.
seeds.germinationNotes: Sow directly into the garden as soon as soil can be worked.

seeds.name: Bloomsdale Spinach
seeds.notes: Large, crinkly leaves. Slow to bolt. Prefers cool weather.
seeds.germinationNotes: Soak seeds overnight before planting to improve germination.

seeds.name: Fordhook Giant Swiss Chard
seeds.notes: Can be harvested as baby greens or full-size leaves. Very productive.
seeds.germinationNotes: Each seed is a cluster of several seeds, so thinning will be necessary.

seeds.name: Common Chives
seeds.notes: Hardy perennial herb. Onion-like flavor. Edible purple flowers.
seeds.germinationNotes: Can be slow to germinate. Keep soil moist.

seeds.name: Slow Bolt Cilantro
seeds.notes: Plant in succession for a continuous supply of leaves (cilantro) and seeds (coriander).
seeds.germinationNotes: Does not transplant well. Sow directly in the garden.

seeds.name: Bouquet Dill
seeds.notes: Used for both its leaves (dill weed) and seeds. Attracts beneficial insects.
seeds.germinationNotes: Grows a long taproot, so it's best to sow directly.

seeds.name: Common Mint
seeds.notes: Aggressive spreader. Best grown in containers to keep it from taking over.
seeds.germinationNotes: Germination can be erratic. Often easier to propagate from cuttings.

seeds.name: Italian Oregano
seeds.notes: Hardy perennial. Spreads to form a nice ground cover. Flavor is best before flowering.
seeds.germinationNotes: Seeds need light to germinate; do not cover them.

seeds.name: Giant of Italy Parsley
seeds.notes: Flat-leaf parsley with excellent flavor. Biennial, but usually grown as an annual.
seeds.germinationNotes: Soak seeds overnight to speed up the notoriously slow germination.

seeds.name: Common Rosemary
seeds.notes: Woody perennial herb. Drought tolerant once established. Needs well-drained soil.
seeds.germinationNotes: Germination from seed can be difficult. Cuttings are a more reliable method.

seeds.name: English Thyme
seeds.notes: Low-growing perennial herb. Great as a ground cover or in rock gardens.
seeds.germinationNotes: Seeds are tiny and slow to germinate. Be patient.

seeds.name: Black Beauty Zucchini
seeds.notes: Bush-type plant. Very productive. Harvest fruits when they are 6-8 inches long for best flavor.
seeds.germinationNotes: Direct sow after the last frost when the soil is warm.

seeds.name: Marigold Sparky Mix
seeds.notes: Companion plant that is said to deter nematodes and other pests. Easy to grow.
seeds.germinationNotes: Easy to grow from seed. Direct sow after last frost or start indoors.

seeds.name: Alaska Nasturtium
seeds.notes: Variegated leaves and edible flowers. Great for trap-cropping aphids.
seeds.germinationNotes: Soak seeds overnight before planting. They prefer poor soil.
